qas.question: What can result in recognizable words?

qas.question: What complicates the traditional ideas of phonemes being perceived as the same allophones?

context: The <b7_0>findings and insights of speech perception and articulation research<b7_0/> <a0_0><b3_0>complicate<b3_0/><a0_0/> the traditional and somewhat intuitive idea of interchangeable allophones being perceived as the same phoneme. First, <b6_0>interchanged allophones of the same phoneme<b6_0/> can result in <a1_0><b4_0>unrecognizable<b4_0/><a1_0/> words. Second, actual speech, even at a word level, is highly co-articulated, so it is problematic to expect to be able to splice words into simple segments without affecting <a2_0><b5_0>speech perception<b5_0/><a2_0/>.
